newsitem.title: PERU: peaceful end sought to crisis.
newsitem.headline: peaceful end sought to crisis.

text.p: Peru's President Alberto Fujimori assured Pope John Paul II in a letter released on Tuesday that he was making every effort to bring the hostage crisis at the Japanese ambassador's residence to a peaceful end.
"Your Holiness can be sure that I will continue making the greatest efforts to ensure that this problem is overcome through peaceful means," Fujimori wrote in the letter, dated Dec. 23.
The short letter thanked the pope for publicly criticising the Marxist rebels who stormed a cocktail party on Dec. 17, taking hundreds of VIP guests hostage.

"I cannot help but criticise such a cruel and immoral type of coercion," the pope told pilgrims at St. Peter's Square in his weekly Angelus message on Sunday. "Violence does not construct the future of a people," he added, speaking in Spanish.
Fujimori has taken a hard line in the hostage crisis, refusing to bow to demands made by rebels belonging to the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) that he free 400 of their jailed comrades.

Roughly 20 heavily armed guerrillas continued on Tuesday to hold about 140 hostages, including the president's brother Pedro Fujimori, two Peruvian government ministers and about 30 Japanese businessmen.
